evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observed and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations, as the evidence from Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim specifically highlights crew interaction failures rather than external factors.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication events, delayed responses, and coordination lapses identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observed and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The described communication failures are representative of a coordination breakdown among crew in the incident dataset.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if the incident was caused solely by procedural deviation without communication failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication among crew and headset operator, and note failures in signaling and warnings, supporting observed communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation without further detailed communication logs.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication events, delayed responses, and coordination lapses identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordination without lapses or miscommunication events.
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication failures.

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination issues such as the trainee stopping and handing over control, and insufficient visual signals leading to lack of warning before collision, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in extent of communication lapses and whether other factors contributed.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim period.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or detected in the evidence
Procedural and communication factors are sufficient to explain the incident
defeaters: Discovery of verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure
Evidence of hardware faults corroborated by bench checks or maintenance records

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8) indicates communication and procedural issues rather than mechanical/control failure; no direct fault codes or hardware malfunctions reported, favoring procedural deviation and communication breakdown over mechanical failure.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 baseline historical interim data set.

assumptions: The TRP marking described corresponds to the baseline historical interim data set for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or not identifiable in the baseline data set, or if personnel were unaware of the marking, the claim would be supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7-H9 shows the TRP marking was present and known to personnel, but communication and procedural issues contributed to the incident, contradicting the claim that an environmental or marking deficiency was present in the baseline data set.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence confirms the baseline data set explicitly; assumptions are made from personnel awareness and marking descriptions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observable and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim period.

assumptions: Crew statements are accurate and complete
Environmental markers were adequate and visible as per H7
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment failure causing the pushback deviation
If environmental markers were inadequate or not visible, supporting environmental deficiency
If communication breakdown was evident causing the deviation rather than procedural error

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation during pushback with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H1-H3 and H8 describe the crew roles and communication, supporting that the deviation was procedural rather than mechanical or environmental. H7 and H9 confirm marker adequacy and trainee awareness, favoring procedural deviation over environmental causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical failure evidence and no environmental deficiency evidence; reliance on crew statements and observations

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations, as the evidence from Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim specifically highlights crew interaction failures rather than external factors.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies communication failure rather than external factors.
No mechanical faults were reported, so mechanical failure is not a competing explanation.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication signals were given but ignored, or if mechanical faults were identified, the robustness of the communication breakdown explanation would be weakened.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were shown to cause confusion, this would challenge the communication breakdown explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe crew interaction failures and lack of effective communication signals, supporting that the breakdown is due to crew coordination rather than external factors or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in whether external factors or procedural deviations contributed; limited direct evidence on external factors.
